climbs.name: Illusion Traverse - South to North
climbs.fa: Dick Culbert, R. Hatch, Monty Laserre, Arnold Shives, September 16 1962

content.description:
This describes the South to North version of the Illusions Traverse, which is the way it's most easily done these days. If you plan on returning the way you came, you'll need to repeat the traverse in the opposite direction (North to South) to get off as described for North Illusion Peak.

From the summit of South Illusion Peak, descend slightly north to a viewpoint above the North-South gap and find a suitable rappel anchor (you may find webbing in place).

Make two long or three short rappels into the North-South col. Note that it's easy to get your rope stuck behind a flake! If using two ropes, this isn't so bad as you can continue with one and grab the stuck rope on your way back).

From the NS Col, circle around the toe of the steep wall on North Illusion's south ridge to the left (west) and scramble up to a ledge.

Off the ledge, climb a half pitch of black-lichened cracks and slabs to reach the spectacular au cheval ridge. Giddyup along the ridge to its south end and a belay. Scramble easily the rest of the way up to North Illusion.



The ridge and gap between the two Illusion Peaks.

Small rack to 3"
The northernmost, and slightly lower, of the two Illusion Peaks
